question: Nossir. I'd gone to tell the wid... to tell Mrs. Heine. Hey there, men. Is your mother home a-tall?
answer: Sheriff Moran, hullo.

question: You go on and play, now.
answer: What can I do for you, Sheriff, Carl's not home y...

question: That's... It's why I'm here. I'm afraid I have some...very bad news to tell you, the...worst...kind of news. Carl died last night. In a fishing accident. In White Sand Bay.
answer: No, Carl's fine, h...

question: We found him, Mrs. Heine. Tangled in his net.
answer: I told him this could happen.

question: These are fishermen, Alvin. They don't talk at all to each other and less to me. Specially gossip.
answer: A gill-netter works through black nights with only himself to talk to. And learns to be silent. They were lonely men and products of geography. ...men who, on occasion, realized that they wished to speak, but couldn't.

question: Figure you'da heard by now. I did. Boy.
answer: Three kids. What's she going to do? Excuse me, Gjovaag. Like the Sheriff, I did not work the sea, and could never merit trust. Or respect. So who talked to him? Out there.

question: All right, look, if you see these boys... Course it is, but a man's dead, William. I got to write my report. I'm not gonna see some article about an investigation, am I? No, I wanna be off the damn record, that's what I want. I mean, if there is a killer, why would you want him all alerted?
answer: Let's say...someday I need some cooperation from you on this thing. Do I get it?

question: Maybe the assailant straightened the cabin. And forgot the cup.
answer: Right. In the middle. Of the floor.

question: Maybe.
answer: I think you testified all the lights were on. Cabin, mast, net lights, picking lights...

question: Yessir, there'd been real heavy fog.
answer: And yet you started the engine right up. With all those lights drawing all night, the batteries had that much charge. Did that strike you odd?

question: Didn't think about it at the time. So no, it didn't strike me odd.
answer: Does it now?

question: A little. Yes. You have to wonder.
answer: You have to wonder. You found three batteries, you say. A D-6 and D-8 in the well. And a spare D-8 on the cabin floor. Correct?

question: It is.
answer: Now I did some measuring down at the chandlery. A D-6 is one inch wider than a D-8. It would be too large for the deceased's well.

question: He's done some on-the-spot refit- ting. You could see the side flange was banged away to make room for the D-6.
answer: But he had a spare D-6, you said. Right there. Why not use that?

question: It was dead. We had it tested. Maybe the D-6 was the spare and he had to use it.
answer: Maybe he carried a spare that was too large to fit. So he'd have to bang out the flange to squeeze it in? Sheriff, how many batteries and what size did you find on defendant's boat?

question: Two D-6's. That's the kind his well was fitted for.
answer: No spare.

question: No.
answer: So the defendant went out fishing for the night with no spare battery, hmmn?

question: Apparently.
answer: I'm curious. The D-6 that was refitted into the deceased's well. Was it exactly the same brand and model as defendant's?

question: I believe so.
answer: Now you've testified that the deceased was a heavy man, and hard to bring out of the net. Is it possible his head struck the transom, or the stern gunnel, or the net roller, as you were bringing him in?

question: I don't think so.
answer: You don't. Think so.

question: He was heavy, but we were real careful. But I don't remember him hitting anything, anywhere.
answer: You don't. Remember. Operating this winch you'd rarely operated before, doing this awkward job of bringing in a drowned man of 235 pounds...is it possible. Possible that he struck his head after death. Possible?

question: ...so when the sheriff returned, you showed him the injury to the deceased's head.
answer: He said, 'Could it be somebody hit him?' And I said, 'You want to play Sherlock Holmes, here?'

question: Did you say more?
answer: I said that if I was playing Sherlock Holmes...I'd maybe look for a... Japanese person. With a bloody gun- butt. A right-handed fella, to be precise.

question: And why. Is that?
answer: Well, I was a doctor in the Jap theater, in the war. I saw those kendo wounds, many times. Looked exactly like this one.

question: Could you tell me what 'kendo' is?
answer: Japanese stick-fighting. They're trained as kids, y'know. To kill with sticks.

question: So this...foam you found in the lungs. How does it get there?
answer: As I testified. It occurs when water, mucus and air are mixed by respiration. I believe I said that. Of course not. The foam means that he went in breathing. That's why the autopsy report identifies drowning as the cause of death.

question: Meaning that he wasn't murdered first, say on the deck of the boat, and then thrown overboard.
answer: Well...

question: Your report says death by drowning, which means he went into the water alive and breathing. And the report is accurate...? Of course, it is. Now as to the head injury. You say made by an object narrow and flat. That is your inference, correct? In your motorcycle example. Those injuries are produced by the head being propelled against an object. Rather than the reverse, yes?
answer: Obviously.

question: Can you tell whether an object moved against the head, or the other way around? Or would both look the same.
answer: The same.

question: So if his head struck something narrow and flat, the gunnel of a boat, a net roller, a fairlead, could that have...
answer: If the head was moving fast enough, but I don't see how it could be.

question: Is it possible?
answer: Sure, anything's poss...

question: Is it fair to say that you do not know for certain which it was.
answer: I already said that, b...

question: And that you can't say for certain whether the head injury was sustained before or after death?
answer: For certain, no.

question: But you are certain that he died by drowning.
answer: For the third time, yes. Can I say something, here?

question: Yes, you can tell me about the minor cut you found on the deceased's right hand. The report says 'recent origin'. How recent? As much as 24 hours before death?
answer: Absolutely not. Probably one or two hours. Four at the most.

question: Are you absol...
answer: Yes, I'm sure.

question: How are the kids?
answer: They need their father.

question: Well. Just a few more days.
answer: I look terrible. Don't sit so straight like Tojo's soldier. The jury will be afraid of you.

question: Okay, I'll hide under the table from now on. That make you happy? I'm not going until you smile.
answer: They'll hear everything. Ishmael. See the yellow one?

question: Have you ever done this?
answer: Never. You're my only. ...so right.

question: No. You must never look at a man directly. This is part of grace.
answer: I don't think the boys on this island. Are impressed. By grace.

question: Hakujin know nothing of life, Hatsue. This is why they fear death. Because life here is separate from Being. It is why they have no soul. Life embraces death, includes it. This truth brings tranquility. You must see yourself...
answer: ...as a leaf. On a great tree.

question: My lessons came from my father. They were different. Or seemed so, at the time. He operated the Review alone, with an integrity and passion for principle that made him a figure of respect. If slightly larger than life. He never spoke of wanting me to succeed him. And, in truth, it was the last job on earth I thought I'd ever want. When I was five, he casually mentioned that if his sleeve got caught in the press, he'd be instantly popped open like a child's balloon, and splattered across the walls. Even his bones would disappear, to be discovered later on the floor, as strips of white confetti. Which, of course, made me certain that life would have no meaning until I could run that teakettle. He was, for better or worse, the only God in my life. I guess it's our nature to resent those we know we can never measure up to... ...which keeps us from accepting the warmth. The way we should. Every summer, after harvest, the Strawberry Festival was Dad's favor- ite story to cover. Good news was his preference. Making him an oddity among journalists. Highlight was crowning the Strawberry Princess. Always a Japanese girl, sort of an unwitting virgin sacrifice to the concept of racial harmony. Senior Year. It was Hatsue. She winked at me. In public. Which was unusual. I had kissed her once, when we were ten. Looking at fish through a glass-bottomed box. It was just an impulse, and no big deal.
answer: He's still got a good grip. We need to dig more.

question: At school, she kept mostly to the Japanese kids, and sort of ignored me. As if all of our times alone together...in the hollow cedar, everywhere...were a secret. I told myself that was good. That it made our friendship special. And didn't mean she was ashamed of it. Necessarily.
answer: Easy. Slow is best.

question: I thought about her. Sometimes, all the time. I knew I was unhappy. But I knew if I told her... It might be a mistake. I could never correct. Do you know what I mean, Hatsue? I've always liked you. I knew in my heart that we would love each other forever. The way she kissed me. She knew it, too. She avoided me for a week. So this way, I could see her without...bothering anyone. I was certain everything would work out. And frightened. By two weeks, I knew I had made the defining mistake of my life. I'd ruined everything.
answer: You followed me, huh?

question: Sorry. It sort of...happened, I just...I followed you. I'm sorry.
answer: I'm all wet.

question: I'm sorry I kissed you on the beach. Let's just forget about it. Forget it happened.
answer: Don't be sorry. I'm not sorry about it.

question: Me neither.
answer: Do you think this is wrong?

question: The best part was that there was a 'this'. To debate the wrongness of. Your friends would. Your dad would kill me with a machete.
answer: We're Japanese, not Mexican, Ishmael. He'll slice you up with a ceremonial sword. My mom. Would be the problem.

question: Why? We're only talking.
answer: I can't hear you.

question: ...you were acquainted with the defendant and his family.
answer: Him and his folks and two brothers and two sisters worked our land. Lived in a picker's cabin at first.

question: So the defendant knew the deceased, your son, even then.
answer: They fished t'gether. Went to school. Carl Junior treated him like a white person. Like any friend.

question: But the dispute began. With the father, yes?
answer: Don't sell, Carl. You'll regret it. Don't go wavin' new church clothes at me. We're not such paupers as sell to Japs, are we? For what, a pouch of fancy pipe tobacco? You wear the pants, doncha? Go ahead, sell our land to a Jap and see what comes of it.

question: Their kids was born here. So when the oldest, that one there, was twenty...last payment gets made, and he could own it. But they missed their last two payments. So that was that. March 1942, orders came down. Japs had eight days before the Army was gonna cart 'em off.
answer: We must leave everything. If you like, you can work our fields, sell berries, keep the money. Otherwise, they just rot.

question: Japs are shrewd. Offer berries he can't use. Soften us up about those two payments still to come.
answer: Today, I have $120 toward next paym... Please, you take. Then, I send more from where I'm going. If not enough, you still have seven acres strawber...

question: Thought you was givin' us those. Didn't you come in here givin' them away? Now you want $130, after our labor and fertilizer. Is that what you come here hopin' on? I spit on him, and he's pretending it didn't happen that way. How could anyone trust people like that? You want more coffee?
answer: No, thank you. Take money, please.

question: You said neither of the last two payments were made. But your husband told defendant's father that he could pay them...what, 'down the road'.
answer: Road ended October 1944, when my husband passed away. I sold all the land to our neighbor, Ole Jurgensen. Got a fair price, this time. And... Sent all their equity back to those Japs down in California. Which I didn't have to do. Specially since my boy was out in the Pacific, gettin' shot at by Japs at the time.

question: Now defendant's father had also died by that point. Where was the defendant? When you sent his family their equity.
answer: In the war. Europe, I believe. They could hardly send him to the Pacific, could they?

question: And when he came home. Did he write you about this? Or phone, perhaps.
answer: Just showed up at my door, big as life and twice as mean. Wanted to talk to my son. He's over the ocean, fighting the Japs. They're just about licked. When Mr. Heine passed away, I couldn't farm the place myself, could I? You're gonna have to talk to Ole abou...

question: Just showed up at my door, big as life and twice as mean. Wanted to talk to my son. He's over the ocean, fighting the Japs. They're just about licked. When Mr. Heine passed away, I couldn't farm the place myself, could I? You're gonna have to talk to Ole abou...
answer: I just did. He didn't know we were one payment away. You didn't tell him Mr. Heine promised my fath...

question: I was s'posed to tell him there's some illegal contract muddling things up? You folks didn't make your pay- ments. In America, bank comes in and repossesses your land. I didn't do anything wrong.
answer: Nothing illegal. Wrong is a different mat...

question: Get out of here.
answer: You sold our land out from under us, Mrs. Heine. You took advantage of the fact that we were gone. You...

question: What do you mean by 'dirty looks'?
answer: Well. Every time I see him in town or somewhere, he's starin' at me with these narrow eyes. Givin' me his mean face.

question: When your son came back from the war, what did he say about all this?
answer: That he'd keep an eye on Miyamoto. Watch out for him.

question: Just three questions. The Miyamoto family bought your seven acres for $4500?
answer: Tried to. Defaulted on their payments.

question: Second question. What did Ole Jurgensen pay you per acre?
answer: A thousand.

question: So that makes what would have been $4500 into $7000, doesn't it? If you sent the equity back, you had a profit of $2500.
answer: Is that your third question?

question: It is.
answer: You done your math right.

question: Were those his exact words? Robbed. He was angry.
answer: Oh, yeh. He said someday he would get his land back.

question: Mr. Jurgensen. Did he offer to buy the seven acres from you?
answer: Oh, yeh. But this is nine year ago, I had my healt, I wasn't wantin' to sell.

question: And then your stroke came this summer. And you put your property on the market, I believe you said September 7. Which, remember, is eight days before Carl Heine died. And who comes Spetember 7, wanting to buy?
answer: Carl Heine came.

question: But Carl was a fisherman. And successful at it.
answer: He said he didn't want that life no more. He'd been saving to buy a farm. He was sorry I got sick. But pretty excited to get back his father's place. Liesel and me. Was happy for him.

question: What makes you think I play?
answer: Your daddy played. I asked, down at the Japanese Community Center. You smoke cigars?

question: I'm not sure. I better check down at the Center.
answer: White or black?

question: You mean, do I like to take the offensive? Or hang back and wait.
answer: Nice. When two fellas understand each other.

question: You must think I like losing.
answer: I think you like learning. Me, too. That's why I come. Bet there's a few things you could teach me. Kendo, for one.

question: Sure. I could take a fishing gaff and split your head open. Right above your left ear. You wouldn't even see it move.
answer: You're wonderin'...how come I never ask. If you did it. Now, you've told me you killed four men. In Germany. So I know you are the kind of man who can kill. When there's a reason. You feel guilty. That you took their lives. That's in your eyes. Prosecutor thinks. What was your reason? To kill Carl Heine. Well, there is the land itself. Raise your children where you were raised. Sleep with your wife at night, 'stead of bein' alone on the sea. There's fairness and honor. You were cheated by that old bitch. Boy, she is something. And prejudice, like you say. Your people locked in a concentration camp. You go off to fight for our country's freedom. Come back to this. But Mr. Hooks has missed the one reason. One reason. You coulda done it. I read you Etta Heine's deposition. So I could watch your mind. Like I do when you move your rook, or when I move mine. And you weren't thinking about her. Or about land. Or about you. No, someone cheats you, you can rise above that. You're a family man. You put them ahead of you, hmmn? Wasn't you she dishonored. Your father was a strong and tireless man. Honest to a fault. Kind, and humble as well... Now this jury is gonna be lookin' at the evidence with one eye. And at you with the oth...

question: Mr. Gudmundsson, we know what that jury is looking at.
answer: Your father needs you. To return to your family. So every time you think about showing that jury strength. Or honor or composure. Or dignity.

question: I should show them an American?
answer: Show them an innocent man.

question: I gave her all of my soul to love. I knew someday we would live in France. Italy. Somewhere. Far from the things that upset her.
answer: I can just feel my spirits soar.

question: Well, I don't do it for just anybody. There can't be any wrong in this, Ha...
answer: I lie to my parents every day. And every night.

question: Well. Since I never told your folks, I guess I'm lying to 'em, too. But you don't hear me complaining about it.
answer: I'm in awe. Of your strength.

question: Hey, Mr. Lamberson, over here! I have a radio, too. Don't you want to be sure I got the message? Just checking. It was a special edition, an extra. My father wrote, 'These people are our neighbors, they have sent their sons to the United States Army...' 'They are no more an enemy than our fellow islanders of German or Italian descent.' I guess courage never inspires the young. Until the danger of it bites their butt.
answer: My father can't get our money from the bank. We have a few dol...

question: It'll be over soon. I can get you money.
answer: It's not going to get better, okay? They arrested Mr. Shirazaki, because his farm is near a navy transmitter. And his family can't leave their house.

question: It's just Pearl Harbor. People are a little crazy, right n...
answer: Look at my face. It's the face of the people who did that. My father hardly speaks English. We're in bad trouble, you have to see that.

question: Maybe we can fix your eyes. Don't let this hurt us, okay? Whatever happens.
answer: It won't. You'll see.

question: Everyone on the island has these things.
answer: You folks have been real polite, and we'll be outta your hair in just a second... That's very nice. From the old country, it appears. Very high class. These are real nice things. They'll take special care of 'em. ...oh yeh, any old country stuff, we have to take.

question: This is only my daughter's scrapbook. For her memories.
answer: Strawberry Princess, huh? You musta been flattered by that. Looks just like y... Maybe. Maybe. But this is still bad, y'see. It's illegal contraband, you were s'posed to turn this stuff in. We, uh... We gotta arrest you. Have to take you to Seattle. Naw, you don't need those. Mister Eee-ma-da-san here is a class act, a real gentleman.

question: Please, reconsider. He has done no bad th...
answer: Well, nobody knows that yet, do they? So, best for an honest man to clear his name for godd and all. Only a few questions in Seattle, okay? Few questions, few answers, the whole thing is over. Simple as that.

question: See, you bring it on yourself. 23 ladies honored by the PTA, you single out three names. And they're all Japanese. That isn't journalism. Because journalism. Is just the facts.
answer: Which facts? You can't print them all. Journalism is balance. Finding the facts folks need to know.

question: Hence. The letters.
answer: 'Seems like you're favoring the Japs, Art. Writin' all about their patriotism and loyalty with nothin' 'bout the treachery.' 'Your newspaper is an insult to all white Americans. Please cancel my subscription and send refund.' The calls are better. 'Jap lovers get their balls cut off and stuffed down their...' Missed the rest. Hanging up will do that. We lost the Price-Rite ads. And Lottie Opsvig's shop, and Larsen's Lumberyard and the Anacortes Cafe. And 30 percent of our subscribers.

question: Integrity is expensive stuff, huh?
answer: Valuable things. Sometimes are. But. I've got the answer. Print four pages. Instead of eight.

question: You're like me. You've learned to be devious.
answer: It's not devious, it's what we have to do. You're leaving tomorrow... You write to my house, and put Kenny Yamashita's name on the return address. It's no big deal. You smell like cedar.

question: So do you. It's your smell I'll miss as much as anything.
answer: Let's get married, okay? I want to marry you. Is that okay? When something that means your whole life. Is the last time ever... God should tell you. Or it's not fair.

question: No. No. It isn't right.
answer: It felt right to me. It felt like getting married.

question: I'll write you.
answer: On Monday, March 30, 1942, the United States Army graciously transported the Imada women to the docks. Lifelong neighbors came to watch. Curiosity masked as kindness... ...with some exceptions.

question: You think we're far enough away now? Mom, whatever this is, they don't keep war secrets this carefully.
answer: Secrets are hard to keep. This letter. Was opened. By mistake. The neighborhood boy. Who taught you to swim?

question: You shouldn't have opened that. It was mi...
answer: How can I ever hope. For your forgiveness. I have written this letter to the boy's parents... Attraction is no crime, certainly among children. The dishonor lies in the concealment. From your families. I know that you know this. I know you have suffered. Even if the hakujin could not. There will be no further letters. No contact of any k...

question: Well, this one here comes off Miyamoto's boat. Matches all his others, worn equal and so on. But this one here... ...comes off third cleat from the stern, port side. And it's brand new. Unlike the rest.
answer: And the next one...?

question: From Carl Heine's boat. All his were like this one, three-strand manila, new condition, braided in loops. Not bowlined like Miyamoto's.
answer: And the last...?

question: Found on Carl's boat, too. Starboard side, second cleat from the stern. But it doesn't match Carl's lines. It matches Miyamoto's. perfect.
answer: So if defendant had tied up to deceased's boat. With that last one. Would those cleats have lined up?

question: You bet. And if Miyamoto there had been in a hurry to cast off, he coulda left this line behind on Carl's boat.
answer: And replaced it later with the new one. That's your inference?

question: Pretty darn clear.
answer: And when you visited defendant on his boat. The evening after Carl Heine's death. Did it seem pretty darn clear to him?

question: Cut your engine, we're coming aboard.
answer: What for, Sheriff?

question: We have a warrant. To search your boat.
answer: Well, what are you looking f... Sheriff, if somebody killed Carl, it sure as hell wasn't me.

question: Then let's get this over with, so you can get to fishin'. Now, cut yor engine. You always run with the well open?
answer: I was checking the cables.

question: D-6s, huh? We'll come back, let's take a look at the stern. See you replaced a mooring line, lately. This one's new.
answer: Naw, I had that around for a while.

question: Sure you did. Help me with this hold cover, willya?
answer: There's nothin' to see. I need to get out there fi...

question: Fish blood, I gaff fish with that.
answer: You gaff with the hook end. Blood's on the butt. Where your hand goes.

question: Sure. Blood gets all over your hand, Sheriff, ask any fisherman.
answer: Gonna have this tested. Now you go home, okay? Wait til you hear from me.

question: Sheriff, I can't afford not to fish toni...
answer: Look, no way I'm lettin' you out there. In a half hour you could be in Canada. I'm sorry, son. But you're under arrest.

question: Now your testimony was interrupted yesterday, when that power line set fire to your mother-in-law's farmhouse... How is your mother-in-law?
answer: She's alright, Nels, thanks for asking.

question: And her farmhouse...?
answer: The damage was considerable. But she's insured. Thanks, again.

question: Well, just to put it back in our minds, could you repeat what you told us. About the type of batteries you found. One Carl's boat.
answer: One D-6 and one D-8 in the well. And a dead D-8 on the deck.

question: Which you inferred was replaced by the D-6, which must have been a spare.
answer: What else could it be?

question: Even though a D-6 is too big, and the flange had to be banged out to squeeze it in. Which makes it a peculiar choice. For a spare.
answer: You said that. That was your testimony.

question: So the blood on the gaff was not fish blood at all. It was human, yes? Type B positive.
answer: Carl Heine's type.

question: But you can't say with any certainty that the blood was his.
answer: No, but as I say, the type is rare. Ten percent of Caucasian males.

question: And the blood could not have belonged to defendant. Seeing that his type is O negative.
answer: That's obvious.

question: You scraped the dried blood from the butt of the gaff. Where a fella's hand goes. And what did you see under your microscope, besides the B positive blood and the wood scrapings...?
answer: Bits of blood and wood. What else would there be?

question: No bits of bone, no particles of scalp, no strands of hair?
answer: None.

question: Well, if the blood got onto the gaff by crushing a man's skull...
answer: I'm a hemotologist, sir, I was asked only t... I don't know.

question: You don't. The coroner testified that Carl Heine had a cut. A fresh cut. Probably one or two hours old. On the palm. Of his right hand. With no bone or scalp or hair present. Would it be more probable that the blood came from crushing a man's skull...
answer: I'm a hemotologist, not a detective.

question: ...or from the cut on his hand. Which is more probable?
answer: It is not my function. To weigh those probabilities.

question: Now this regiment you were training, the 442nd, this was all Nisei boys...
answer: They were Japanese-American boys, yes sir.

question: And you were generally experienced in training men for hand-to-hand combat.
answer: It was my specialty, sir, I trained several thousand over the years.

question: So. Wide cross-section of men to evaluate. And the day that the defendant volunteered for this... demonstration. Did you find him eager?
answer: More than eager. He was out to make a point.

question: And what point. Was that.
answer: Anyone.

question: Anyone.
answer: SIR!

question: You don't salute me, you don't call me 'sir', soldier, I'm an enlisted man. And nobody bows in this man's Army, you're in America, son. Not Japan.
answer: I'm sorry, sir, force of habit.

question: No more 'sir'. That's the last of that. The exercise is avoiding thrusts. Now, first y... Are you ready for some simulated combat, soldier?
answer: For combat. Sergeant.

question: I can.
answer: What could I tell him? There's my mother to think about. You know what she'd say? I said I'd think it over, talk with you.

question: Did he go away angry?
answer: He kept talkin' about those seven acres belonged to his father, and how honorable and decent his father was. His meaning was pretty clear. And I didn't much like it.

question: You had a scrap.
answer: I couldn't...talk to him. Look, Kabuo's a Jap. And I don't hate Japs, but I don't like 'em neither. It's hard to explain if you weren't in the war, you know?

question: He's not a Jap. You don't mean that. You and he were friends.
answer: We were kids.

question: So your husband said he's think it over. Encouraged Mr. Miyamoto to believe he might sell to h...
answer: I wouldn't say encouraged.

question: Well, he didn't say 'no', did he? Didn't say no hope existed.
answer: Not in those words.

question: So the defendant was encouraged to hope. Or could have been.
answer: I guess so.

question: I guess you'd have to guess. Not having been there with them. Having to guess whether your husband's report was word for word accurate.
answer: Carl never lied.

question: Of course not. But it was emotional. A friend's plea set against his mother's attitude. Those 'dirty looks'. Defendant ever aim one of those at you?
answer: He had no reason to.

question: Carl ever say he got one?
answer: I can't speak for him.

question: My father had bought the DeSoto fifteen years before. Driving it reminded me of him. Which I considered a neutral fact... Actually, it was pleasant. Snow made all the fields into one. The notion that one man might kill another for a small patch, made no sense. But I knew such things occurred. Having been to war and all. May I give you folks a lift? I didn't look at her. I thought that would be best.
answer: My father is grateful for your kindness. But he will free his car, shortly.

question: Okay, I'll help. I know it's caused you trouble. But don't you think the snow is beautiful, coming down?
answer: This trial is unfair. You should write about that in your newspaper. Just that. This trial is wrong, they are calling a good man a killer. It is only about prejudice, and that is unfair.

question: We all expect the world to be fair. As if we have some right t...
answer: I don't mean everyone. Just people who can do things because they can arrest people or convict them. Or run a newspaper.

question: Maybe I should write a column. What do you think?
answer: What do you think?

question: I think people. Should be fair.
answer: Will you write that?

question: I might just. I was part of her life again. I was a person. You have the night watch? On the radio.
answer: Since September. Last guys got transferred.

question: And you keep the records, or contribute to 'em.
answer: Shorthard the radio transmis- sions, write 'em up, file 'em in a cabinet. Nobody ever looks. Just take up space.

question: All kinds of radio transmissions? Fisherman in trouble, and such.
answer: All kinds. Make yourself at home.

question: I'd been back two months. It was the first time I'd seen her.
answer: Hello.

question: I couldn't say anything. I just stood there, hating her.
answer: I'm sorry about your arm. Kabuo and I. Are very sor...

question: The Japs did it. They shot it off. At Tarawa. I'm sorry, I'm sorry I said that. I'm sorry about everything. All of it. September 16. At 1:42 A.M., the dead of night. The S.S. West Corona, a Greek-owned freighter, was lost. In heavy fog. They radioed to the lighthouse. They would have to dogleg, bisecting Ship Channel Bank. And Seaman Philip Milholland wrote that down. In his report. Carl Heine drowned. In Ship Channel Bank. And his watch stopped. At 1:47. A huge freighter plowing through. Throwing a wake big enough to fling any man overboard. How long you have this detail?
answer: Me and Smoltz came on dogwatch September 16.

question: You mean, early morning the 16th?
answer: No, night of the 16th, morning the 17th. We replaced two guys named Miller and Milholland. They got transferred that day. Out to Cape Flattery.

question: Some seaman's loast report. Stuffed in a cabinet, good as lost forever. No one knows.
answer: You get what you come for?

question: Guess I'm not completely sure. What that was. I left the grocery, and wrote a letter. I apologizes from my heart. I should never have said that word to her. I never would again. It sat in my desk for two weeks. Before I threw it away. I knew her car. And sometimes when I'd see it, I'd...drive that way. At a distance. Can I talk to you?
answer: I'm married, Ishmael. It isn't right for us to be alone. People will t...

question: There's no one here, and I've got to talk to you. Don't you owe me that? I'm like a dying person. I don't sleep. I tell myself this can't go on, but it goes on anyway.
answer: I did a terrible thing, Ishmael. I knew what you felt. And what I didn't. And I never found the courage to tell you.

question: You'll think this is crazy, but all I want is to hold you. Just once. And smell your hair.
answer: You have to hear this, I can never touch you, Ishmael. Not once, not ever. There's no half- way. As much as I know it hurts you, you have to let this go.

question: Look, I want to forget you, I do. I think if you hold me, just this once, I can walk away and never speak to you again. Please? As one human being to another, just because I'm miserable and don't know where to turn. I need to be in your arms. If it's just for thirty seconds.
answer: I hurt for you. Whether you'll ever believe that or not. I feel sick sometimes, with the guilt of what I've done to you. And I can't make it right. To hold you would be wrong and deceitful. You're going to have to live without holding me, that is the truth of the way things are. Things end. They do. Get on with your life. Get on with your life.

question: I drove from the lighthouse to my mother's place. I brought her some groceries.
answer: Your father thought that heavy snow was God's kindness. Despite the hardship, it brought us beauty... ...and reminded us. Of our place in things. You don't believe in God anymore.

question: Agnostics don't believe or disbelieve, Ma. We just don't pretend we know.
answer: We don't know God, we feel Him. You felt Him as a child. I remember.

question: That's a long time ago. What a child feels...that's different.
answer: Spend the night, will you? Don't go back out into all that snow.

question: I felt Milholland's report in my pocket. And wondered why I wasn't telling her. Telling someone. What I'd found.
answer: You've been busy with that trial, I suppose. Such a travesty... They only arrested that poor soul because he's Japanese.

question: Seattle boys think he's guilty. They say the evidence is rock solid.
answer: They're not his neighbor, like you are. He is a husband, a father, he risked his life for their country. The same as you.

question: Those aren't the facts that matter.
answer: Well, folks are pretty cold. And folks who believe in nothing else...they're cold, too. I've tried to understand your unhappiness, all these years. Having gone to war, losing your arm... But other boys came back. And pushed on. They found girls, and married, had babies...

question: Someday I'll get lucky, too.
answer: Your father fought at Belleau Wood, it took him years to get over it. Nightmares, tears, b...

question: ...but he found you.
answer: It isn't the war, Ishmael. All those years growing up. You never had a real girl of your own. And I know you have it in you to love. I know that much. I wish I knew more.

question: Hopeful. Is the word I would use.
answer: But Carl didn't say yes.

question: He didn't say no. That was Kabuo's point. Given how Carl's mother felt, Carl was still willing to consider selling to us. It was a good sign.
answer: Well, in the week that followed, the week before Carl's death... did your husband pursue him?

question: No. Kabuo did not wish to beg, he respected Carl's right to reflect. He was sure Carl would do the honorable thing. The night of the 15th, Kabuo helped Carl at sea. With his dead battery. Right there, on the boat, they agreed. $8400 for the seven acres, $800 down. They shook on it. Kabuo was so excited when he came home.
answer: And when did you first learn. That Carl had drowned?

question: One o'clock, that afternoon, from a clerk at Petersen's.
answer: Your husband came home agitated, after his encounter with the deceased?

question: I said 'excited'. Not agitated, he was excited in the sense of being overjoyed.
answer: You were...overjoyed yourself, to hear the news?

question: Happy for him. And relieved.
answer: So, then, you...and your husband... must have called friends, relatives, to tell them the amazing news. Yes? Really? Didn't call your mother, your sisters, about starting a new life. Your husband never tells his brothers that the family honor is vindicated.

question: We hear how Carl...passed away. Only a few hours later.
answer: Your husband returned at, what, seven o'clock?

question: Closer to eight.
answer: So, five hours. Plenty of time for a call. He was 'excited', you say. In the sense of being 'overjoyed'.

question: We are...cautious people. You would say conservative. There would be time for celebrating with others when a paper was signed.
answer: You thought the deceased might... break his promise?

question: Of course not. We're just not quick to run and boast. In case something went wrong.
answer: And then, something did. Carl Heine was found dead. With his head crushed.

question: Yes, and then, what was there to call about? Everything was up in the air.
answer: Up in the air? Was that your reaction? I would suggest that more happened than a land sale evaporating. A man died, Mrs. Miyamoto. A husband and father of small children had his skull bashed in! I see. Well, did you come forward to tell Sheriff Moran what you knew? The encounter in the fog, the...dead battery, was it?

question: We discussed that. And decided not to.
answer: Why not?

question: Because the facts could be misconstrued as murder.
answer: But if truth was on your side, whatever were you worried about?

question: Trials aren't only about truth, Mr. Hooks. Even though they should be. They're about what people believe is true.
answer: So you hid the truth. Deliberately.

question: We were afraid. Silence seemed better. To come forward seemed like a mistake.
answer: Well, it seems to me... Doesn't it seem to you, Mrs. Miyamoto, that your mistake was in being deceitful? Concealing information during the course of a sheriff's investigation.

question: It seems human. To me.
answer: I suppose that you mean this excuses concealing the truth. Then why ahouls any of us believe you now? Question withdrawn, you may step down.

question: You're implying th...
answer: I said. No further questions.

question: Thirty years fishing alone. Ever had an occasion to board another man's boat except in an emergency? Maybe to socialize or some such? Now, Mister Gi...
answer: Unwritten rule of the sea. We don't bother each other, stick to ourselves. Ask anybody.

question: Now if you wanted to kill a man. Think you'd try boarding against his will, and hitting him with a fishing gaff?
answer: It's a joke. Maneuver up to Carl's boat? Tie your lines fast? Come aboard? All against Carl's will? It's the stupidest suggestion I ever heard of.

question: I'm sorry about that. It wasn't mine in the first place. So the fishing gaff method wouldn't make sense?
answer: Couldn't get on the boat. I'd just shoot the feller. Then tie up, throw him inta th' drink. And skip bein' the first gill-netter in history to make a successful forced boarding.

question: Now the sheriff believed that the D-6 battery in Carl's well was Carl's own spare. Even though it was too large f...
answer: No sense to have any at all., even the right size. It's like having an extra battery in the trunk of your car. Nobody does. Boat has two batteries. Lose one you run off the other til morning. Carl musta lost both, so Miyamoto there gave him one a his.

question: Course, if Carl lost both batteries, dead in the water, his radio wouldn't work. So how would he signal for help?
answer: Compressed air horn, most likely. Hope to God some man hears you in that fog.

question: All right, what if the defendant heard? So Carl let him aboard, to help. And then the fishing gaff?
answer: You mean Miyamoto followed him out there, and sucker-punched him?

question: Well, what if?
answer: Now, how is Miyamoto gonna know in advance? That Carl loses two batteries. Must happen once ever' 20 years or so.

question: Thank you, Mr. Gillanders. Thank you for coming down, in this cold weather.
answer: Well, it does seem mighty warm in here. Specially for Mr. Hooks.

question: Rephrase. Do you agree that he might tie up to the defendant's bo...
answer: So why's the D-6 in Carl's well?

question: Who's to say? Maybe it was just a spare, after all. Or maybe the defendant left it, as a potential alibi. In case somebody saw him in Ship Channel Bank. In case we put two and two together, knowing of the hostility. Between the families. My question is. Could Carl have tied up to help the defendant?
answer: It coulda happened. And if I start to say it's doubtful, you'd probl'y say 'no further questions', right?

question: But the toughest scenario. Is the one Hooks will never raise.
answer: And what's that?

question: That you came upon Carl by accident. Like you said. Gave him the battery. Like you said. Asked him about the seven acres. Like you said. Only. He said no. And something...happened. That you'd never planned. Because you're not a cold-blooded killer.
answer: I'm more a hot-blooded killer, huh? Like a soldier. Like a samurai.

question: You won't hear that from Hooks. Because the charge is first-degree murder, which requires premeditation. He can't change the charge. So if the jury thinks you did kill. but only in the heat of anger. They have to acquit. And you couldn't. Be. Re-tried.
answer: You want me to say that.

question: I want you. To tell the truth.
answer: You think that is the truth.

question: I told your wife. Trials aren't always so much about actual truth. As about what folks believe is true. That's sad. And it's real.
answer: And what do you believe?

question: My batteries are drawed down, both of 'em. ALternator belts were loose.
answer: No sweat. We'll pull one a mine, get ya started. You lashed up a lantern? 'Gainst a fog like this?

question: Lantern and a air horn. That's all I got, without my juice. Don't know how long it's take to get a charge...
answer: Keep it tonight. We'll catch fish. I'll see ya back on the docks...

question: Seven acres. I'm wonderin' what you'd pay for 'em. Just curious, is all.
answer: What are you sellin' 'em for? Why don't we start there.

question: Did I say I was selling? But if I was, I'd have to figure you want 'em real bad. Oughta charge a sall fortune, maybe... Then again. Maybe you'd want your battery back.
answer: The battery's in, that's done with. Besides, you'd do the same for m...

question: ...might do the same. I have to warn you 'bout that, chief. I'm not screwed together like I used to be. Hell, I'm sorry, okay? About the whole damn mess. If I'd a been around, my mother wouldn't a pulled it off that way.
answer: I killed men who looked just like you, pig-fed German bastards. And their blood don't wash off so easy. So don't talk to me about Japs, you big Nazi son of a bitch.

question: I am a bastard. I'm a big Hun Nazi son of a bitch. And I still got your bamboo fishing rod.
answer: Oh, yeh?

question: Hid it from my mom. Caught a mess a sea runs. Damn thing's still in my closet. $1200 an acre, that's what I paid Ole, won't take a dime less. You got no choice on that.
answer: Didn't say I was buyin' did I? What you want down? Just bein' curious, is all.

question: A thousand down. We'll sign papers t'morrow.
answer: Eight hundred. And it's a deal.

question: For the life of me, sir, I cannot imagine why you kept this story from the sheriff.
answer: As my wife testified, we were considering it.

question: Actually, she said you had decided. Decided not not come forward. Except even when Sheriff Moran arrested you. You said nothing about seeing Carl. At that point, you were already under suspicion. The battery story explained things. If the story was true...and not simply something you thought up later... Why. Didn't you. Tell it?
answer: Sheriff said right off, I was under suspicion. I didn't have a lawyer...

question: But even after you had an attorney. You still claimed to know nothing. Claimed not to have seen Carl. Am I correct?
answer: Yes. Initially.

question: Well, 'initially' is an interesting word, sir. You'd been arrested, you had a lawyer, and you still claimed ignorance!
answer: I should have told everything right away. I know that now, and I regret it.

question: Should have told 'everything'. Meaning, you should have told the truth. Nothing to say? My apologies. Do you regret not telling the truth?
answer: I have told the truth.

question: You mean, this morning. The new story, the battery story. That one is the truth? That's a question, sir. I see. Now what happened the day Carl Heine was found? Before your arrest.
answer: I slept til one-thirty, when my wife woke me up with the news. We talked for a few hours. I left at six and went straight to my boat.

question: Didn't go anywhere else? No errands, no purchases? Just straight to the boat. That's the truth.
answer: Yes.

question: Well, the sheriff found two batteries in your well. If you left one with Carl Heine, how is that possible?
answer: I had a spare battery in my shed. I brought it down, and put it in just before the sheriff showed up.

question: Conveniently, in your shed. Only you didn't mention that a moment ago. Why does this battery story change every time a new question is raised?
answer: You asked if I went straight to the boat. I did. With the battery.

question: Did you write that column?
answer: I did. But the jury won't s...

question: It's not for the. They only get to convict him. It's the judge who decides. If he'll hang. You don't think he did this.
answer: I know he didn't.

question: Come to supper, tonight. My mother would be proud to have you with us.
answer: I can't. Tell your mom. I want a rain check.

question: Won't take two.
answer: Please, sit down... She told me you're writing a column. We're very grateful. She. Said you two go way back... That's nice.

question: You said there was a lantern in his hand. When you found him in the fog. And another one. Lashed to the mast?
answer: That's right.

question: Two. Lanterns.
answer: If I did the math right.

question: It's the sheriff's math. I'm wondering about.
answer: Blackmail. That's all it is.

question: I call it keeping your promise. We said if I ever needed some cooperation from you...
answer: You threatened me, Chambers, pure and simple. And what idiot's gonna believe some cock and bull story that I made a deal to keep stuff outta your paper? Not that anybody reads your paper.

question: Same idiots who'll believe you cracked this case. When I tell 'em you did.
answer: See, no lantern. Never shoulda given you that inventory in the first place.

question: You wanna see that in the papers? Don't ever touch something at a cri... One lantern. Like the inventory says. Sorry to disappoint you.
answer: Actually. I was hoping you got it right. What's that, up there?

question: Nothin'. Bits of string.
answer: Pieces of twine aren't nothing.

question: Here now, what are you fixin' to do?
answer: Have a look. At nothing.

question: You can't go up there, touch things... You gonna climb that with one arm?
answer: You're right. I better use two.

question: You're right. I better use two.
answer: There's lots of 'em, Art, look.

question: A dozen or more, all figure eights. All cut clean through on an angle.
answer: And look at that streak of rust, across the mast.

question: It's on the twine, too. But it's not r...
answer: Don't prove there was two lanterns. Coulda been the one in the cabin.

question: There's a stretch of ground between guessin' and provin', Sheriff. I'll give you that.
answer: What do you think you're lookin' at now?

question: Well. It's imaginative... ...I'll give you that.
answer: It's the way it happened, I know it is.

question: No, you don't. That report. About the freighter? You didn't find that tonight, did you? You went right to the cell. Then to the boat. Then here. How long did you know about the freighter? This tastes horrible, hmmn?
answer: You're wondering why I held it.

question: I'm wondering how the judge is gonna like my waking up his old bones. in the middle of the night. Your daddy. Was quite a feller.
answer: Yes, he was.

question: He's looking down. And he's not thinking 'bout the man you were yesterday. He's proud of the man you are tonight. That's what counts.
answer: To my father. Everything counts.

question: All right, let's say that twine had been there to lash a lantern. That it had come from the shuttle of twine found in the deceased's pocket. Now to re-open a trial that had gone to jury...new evidence should be pretty important. Tell us why that lantern would be so significant.
answer: Well. It shows the prosecutor was wrong. It was Carl's boat that was dead in the water. Or he'd never have put up the lantern.

question: Now you believe there were two lanterns when defendant arrived. One in Carl's hand. The second lashed to the mast.
answer: That's what Mr. Miyamoto reported, and he'd have no reason to lie. He couldn't know that it would help his case.

question: Well, why does it?
answer: Because the second lantern, the one on the mast. Was never found. So we have to ask... ...where did it go? Maybe it went. Where Carl went. Over the side.

question: So how does this fit with what you told us at the start? The freighter that plowed through Ship Channel Bank...
answer: That's when he fell.

question: Fell.
answer: Miyamoto gave him the battery, and left. Carl's boat was running, he goes back to fishing. But at some point, he thinks of the lantern...

question: Still lashed to the mast.
answer: He figures a perfectly good lantern could get banged around up there. So he climbs up. To cut it down.

question: Just as the freighter comes through? Isn't that quite a coincidence?
answer: Coincidences happen. You run a yellow light just as a car comes out of nowhere. Split-second tragedy happens every day. Or maybe...

question: Maybe...?
answer: Maybe Carl picks up something about the freighter on his radio, which is now working. Same report Milholland heard. And that makes him get the lantern fast. Before the freighter's wake can bang it around.

question: But you could be wrong. He could have climbed up earlier.
answer: Then where's the lantern? And where's the knife?

question: The knife. What knife?
answer: Coroner found an empty knife sheath on Carl's belt. But they never found the knife. He climbs up. His hand wound still bleeding. That's the blood I found on the mast. And the twine. He cuts the lantern free, the freighter's wake hits, the boat rolls hard, his bloody hand slips. tracing blood along the mast... He falls. The lantern, the knife, go into the water. Same as Carl. And inside the cabin, a coffee cup falls off the counter. But there's no one around. To pick it up.

question: Still a coincidence. Timing and all.
answer: The freighter started through at 1:42. The sea water seeped into Carl's watch and stopped it. At 1:47.

question: Still and all. Carl was a strong swimmer, he m...
answer: He hit his head. On the way in.

question: You think so?
answer: The sheriff and the deputy and I inspected the deck closely. We found a small fracture in the wood of the gunnel. Just below the mast.

question: Well, anything coulda caused that.
answer: Anything. That had a blond hair.

question: I have to start reading your paper more closely. You're quite a storyteller. Everything had to happen just right. For your little story to fly. I mean, a blond hair could be on that gunnel for a lot of reasons.
answer: I'm sorry, was there a question in there?

question: Well, the freighter. The twine. The blood. The knife. The cup. The watch. The second battery. The phantom lantern. The fishing gaff. The cracked gunnel. The skull wound. The blond hair. That's eleven things...
answer: Twelve.

question: I stand corrected, sir. And you have a neat explanation for every one of them. And since you confess this is all pure guesswork. What is your expertise, sir, are you a detective of sorts?
answer: My expertise. Is that I'm a journalist. And journalism. Is balance. Finding the facts folks need to know. Then putting them together. So truth is revealed.

question: But isn't the truth that there are several other ways to explain each of these twelve pieces.
answer: Oh, yes. But no other way. To explain them all. And since they all happened. This is the only explanation that's the truth.

question: Your line of work. You must meet a lot of men play fast and loose with the truth.
answer: Like you couldn't believe.

question: Well, the defendant is a liar. He's confessed that much. And his explanation is...he was afraid. Afraid that the good folks of this jury. Would be too stupid to understand. Too prejudiced to be fair. You buy that? Greedy.
answer: He didn't want to lose any more. He'd lost a lot in the war, you see. I had sent him away. To a concentration camp. But a nice one. Far less brutal than the Nazis. Because I'm a civilized person.

question: I asked you a question, you're writing a tract, h...
answer: That's how journalists. Answer questions. May I answer the question, Your Honor? Anout the defendant's motivation to lie?

question: I didn't say. I did it alone. So there he was. His father lost his health there, finally died. They lost more than Etta Heine's seven acres. They lost their liberty, their dignity. Their ideals about this country. They lost their trust in us. We had treated them worse than animals. How would we now see tham. As human beings? This man lost a lot in the war. He didn't want now to lose his babies. Or the woman who loves him. And my expertise in this, sir. Is that I lost a lot in the war myself. And the fact that I am the only witness. Who placed his right hand upon the Holy Bible. Is the least of it, sir. I assure you of that.
answer: Well, sir. I hate to spoil the soliloquy, I truly do. But the fact is...you are not on trial here. Nor is Judge Fielding, or myself. Nor the good people of this jury. For events that took place twelve years ago. And I wouldn't blame these good people if they were a mite resent- ful. At a tactic that insults their intelligence.

question: That's curious. I was appealing to their intelligence.
answer: Were you, sir? Can you prove one word of all your fancy story?

question: No, sir, I can't. Not beyond a reasonable doubt. It's fortunate that the man who needs to prove his fancy story. Beyond a reasonable doubt. Is someone else. I'm sorry, Mr. Hooks. I apologize for my tone. This is not a contest. Between you and me. For it is not. As Mr. Gudmundsson so wisely put it. A small trial. In a small place. I lost more in that war than anyone will ever know. So did a lot of folks. And what we got back in return... ...was a country. Where a man was innocent. Until we proved him guilty. Whether we all got cheated. We're about to find out.
answer: All things considered... ...you were adequate. I could make a few quibbles, but I am loathe to hurt your feelings.

question: Cigarette?
answer: I'll take two. One for later.

question: I've always thought so.
answer: If I whistle. Those boys'll see you, and come runnin'. You're the story today.

question: You ever been strangled by a single hand?
answer: Naw, I've seen what that can do to a pack of cigarettes.

question: Better take three... Maybe they'll keep us waiting.
answer: Prejudice is like any obsession. There's a reason why we can't let go. Even when we want to.

question: A reason.
answer: Hate or love. It works the same.

question: Your client's wife ever mention? We go way ba... We don't let go, you s...
answer: It's a rare thing. Takes a turning point. You gave this jury three chances. To turn. No other way to explain it all. That was one. I caught some of 'em fluttering, waking up, on that. Second. You sent him to Manzanar, and you didn't do it alone. I liked that one, they didn't. No surprise. Last. You gave your arm. To buy this woman back her husband. Are they gonna cheat you out of that? Some let go, some don't. Where did you?

question: She was an honest person. Doing the best she could.
answer: The prosecutor, the judge, cut her off. She was desperate. Her husband helpless...I was helpless... You couldn't let her. Be helpless. When this verdict is read. She may look for your face. Here's what she needs to see
